title: 104_hr3420
content: TEMPORARY SUSPENSION OF 4.3 CENTS OF FUEL TAX RATES. During a temporary rate reduction period, the fuel tax rates will be temporarily suspended by 4.3 cents per gallon for gasoline, diesel fuel, aviation fuel, and fuel used on inland waterways. During the temporary rate reduction period, certain fuel tax rates will be suspended by 4.3 cents per gallon for diesel fuel, special fuels, gasoline used in noncommercial aviation, and certain methanol or ethanol fuels. Additionally, compressed natural gas will also receive comparable treatment with no tax imposed during this period. Fuel subject to tax during this period will have specified rates reduced by 4.3 cents per gallon under certain refund rules. Coordination with highway trust fund deposits will also be ensured. During the temporary rate reduction period, fuel tax rates will be suspended by 4.3 cents per gallon for certain fuels. Coordination with highway trust fund deposits will be ensured. The amendment made by this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 2. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. Floor stock refunds are provided for in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. If tax has been imposed on any liquid before the enactment of this Act and is held by a dealer for sale, a credit or refund will be given to the taxpayer for the excess amount paid. Claims for credit or refund must be filed within 6 months of the enactment of this Act. The Act allows for a credit or refund to taxpayers for excess tax paid on liquids held by a dealer before the enactment date, provided the dealer requests it within 3 months. No credit or refund is allowed for liquids held in retail stocks. Definitions for "dealer" and "held by a dealer" are based on section 6412 of the Code. Similar rules from section 6412 apply. For this section, subsections (b) and (c) of section 6412 of the Code will be applicable. SEC. 3. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of a floor stocks tax of 4.3 cents per gallon on liquids held on January 1, 1997, with payment due by June 30, 1997. Liquid considered "held by a person" if title has passed to them. The tax imposed on gasoline, diesel fuel, and aviation fuel does not apply if held for exempt uses or in a vehicle tank. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. No tax is imposed on gasoline or diesel fuel held in the tank of a motor vehicle or motorboat. An exception applies for certain amounts of fuel held on January 1, 1997, with specific gallon limits. Submission of required information to the Secretary is necessary for this exception. For tax purposes, fuel exempt from tax is not considered. Controlled groups are treated as one person, following specific criteria. Under regulations prescribed by the Secretary, principles similar to those for controlled groups apply to nonincorporated persons under common control. All provisions of law applicable to gasoline, diesel fuel, and aviation fuel taxes also apply to floor stock taxes imposed under subsection (a). The floor stock taxes imposed under subsection (a) are subject to the same regulations as gasoline, diesel fuel, and aviation fuel taxes. SEC. 4. OFFSETTING REDUCTIONS IN DEFENSE BUDGET AUTHORITY. The Secretary of Defense must cancel budget authority to reduce Department of Defense outlays by $2.9 billion. A report must be submitted to Congress detailing the programs affected by the budget cuts. Amounts cancelled will have an impact as specified. The Secretary of Defense must cancel budget authority to reduce Department of Defense outlays by $2.9 billion. Amounts cancelled under this section shall not be available for obligation for any purpose. Definitions for available budget authority and current defense procurement accounts are provided.
